Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding Dynamic Behaviors of Tissue Welding for High Quality Electrosurgical Tissue Joints

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Tissue welding, also known as electrosurgical joining of tissues, is a process used in surgery to seal blood vessels in order to control bleeding. It uses a combination of electro-resistive heating and mechanical clamping to elevate tissue temperature and denature collagen, such that separate tissue can be reconnected. Tissue welding is becoming more prevalent because of the increasing use of minimally invasive surgical procedures, where only a few small incisions are made to access the surgical site. In these cases, it is difficult to use the traditional hand suturing technique to seal wounds because of limited accessibility. There are more than 1.5 million surgical procedures done in US annually that involve the tissue welding process. The overall market size for electrosurgical devices is more than 1 billion dollars in US in 2011 and is increasing by 5-6% each year. Despite its importance, the quality of tissue welding joints is often inconsistent due to the lack of good understanding and proper quality control of the tissue welding process. Failed joints can cause severe bleeding, prolonged operative time, and impaired surgical outcomes. This research will lead to more consistent and reliable tissue joints, thus improved healthcare safety and quality. It will also lead to the advancement of electrosurgical tools for tissue welding, and increase the competitiveness of US medical device manufacturing.

The research team will study the dynamic behavior of tissue's thermal and electrical impedances during the tissue welding process and to correlate these behaviors to the joint strength. The tissue thermal and electrical impedances will be experimentally determined at different levels of thermal dose. The results will be used to develop a multi-physics finite element model to predict spatial and temporal temperature distribution of the joint site from the electrical energy input. The effect of clamping force on the contact area between the electrosurgical tool and tissue will be explored. A series of tissue joints using various levels of thermal dose and mechanical clamping force will be conducted and the strength of these joints tested to establish a weld quality prediction model. The fundamental understanding obtained from this research on biological material responses to heat will find many applications in other surgical processes, such as laser and ultrasonic tumor ablation.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to gain a better understanding of how tissue properties change during the electrosurgical tissue joining process.  By using this new understanding, we can improve the quality of tissue joints while reducing the thermal damages to the surroundings.  The major outcomes of this project include:

  1. A hybrid method to estimate the tissue's thermal conductivity with various thermal dose by combing experimental measurement and the inverse heat transfer method.  The tissue's thermal conductivity has not been correlated to thermal dose previously.  This is the first experimental investigation of thermal-dependent tissue thermal conductivity in the literature and the developed method can be used to measure the thermal conductivity of other types of tissue.

  2. The change of tissue's thermal conductivity is characterized by thermal dose which accounts for the thermal history that the tissue undergoes.  A regression model to predict the tissue's thermal conductivity based on the thermal dose is established, as shown in Fig. 1.  This regression model can be implemented in a finite element model to more accurately predict the temperature distribution of tissue during the joining process, as shown in Fig.2.

  3. A new index, specific strength, is introduced to characterize the tissue joining process with different input parameters.  The specific strength is defined as the joining strength divided by the input energy to the tissue.  The specific strength is a measure of the efficiency of converting energy to the joining strength.  The higher the specific strength, the less energy is needed to achieve the same level of the joining strength and thus resulting less thermal spread and potential thermal damages.  It is found that a higher compression level can lead to a higher specific strength.

  4. The dynamic electrical impedance of tissue during the tissue joining process is characterized, as shown in Fig. 3.  When a different compression level is applied, the impedance will change differently over the tissue joining process.   When a higher compression level is applied, a shorter period of joining time is needed to create a strong tissue joint.  It is now possible to monitor the tissue joining process by measuring the impedance in real-time.

  5. A new concept of the tissue joining process is proposed and validated to achieve a higher specific strength.  This concept utilizes a pair of small electrodes to apply the compression on smaller areas sequentially to complete the tissue joint.  By compressing a smaller area, less force is needed to create a higher compression level which is beneficial when instrumenting this concept on a new device to be used in minimally invasive surgery.  This concept can achieve three times of specific strength higher than that of the traditional single-compression joining process, as shown in Fig. 4.

Modified by: Roland K Chen

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project aims to gain a better understanding of how tissue properties change during the electrosurgical tissue joining process. By using this new understanding, we can improve the quality of tissue joints while reducing the thermal damages to the surroundings. The major outcomes of this project include: A hybrid method to estimate the tissue's thermal conductivity with various thermal dose by combing experimental measurement and the inverse heat transfer method. The tissue's thermal conductivity has not been correlated to thermal dose previously. This is the first experimental investigation of thermal-dependent tissue thermal conductivity in the literature and the developed method can be used to measure the thermal conductivity of other types of tissue. The change of tissue's thermal conductivity is characterized by thermal dose which accounts for the thermal history that the tissue undergoes. A regression model to predict the tissue's thermal conductivity based on the thermal dose is established, as shown in Fig. 1. This regression model can be implemented in a finite element model to more accurately predict the temperature distribution of tissue during the joining process, as shown in Fig.2. A new index, specific strength, is introduced to characterize the tissue joining process with different input parameters. The specific strength is defined as the joining strength divided by the input energy to the tissue. The specific strength is a measure of the efficiency of converting energy to the joining strength. The higher the specific strength, the less energy is needed to achieve the same level of the joining strength and thus resulting less thermal spread and potential thermal damages. It is found that a higher compression level can lead to a higher specific strength. The dynamic electrical impedance of tissue during the tissue joining process is characterized, as shown in Fig. 3. When a different compression level is applied, the impedance will change differently over the tissue joining process. When a higher compression level is applied, a shorter period of joining time is needed to create a strong tissue joint. It is now possible to monitor the tissue joining process by measuring the impedance in real-time. A new concept of the tissue joining process is proposed and validated to achieve a higher specific strength. This concept utilizes a pair of small electrodes to apply the compression on smaller areas sequentially to complete the tissue joint. By compressing a smaller area, less force is needed to create a higher compression level which is beneficial when instrumenting this concept on a new device to be used in minimally invasive surgery. This concept can achieve three times of specific strength higher than that of the traditional single-compression joining process, as shown in Fig. 4.
